This is comfort food on steroids times ten! Starters. Roasted corn soup pistachio pesto, vanilla, summer truffle crème fraîche ($9). What a treat to start our evening. I had the grilled monterey bay squid with pope's beans, meyer lemon, calabrian chile aioli ($10). Flavours came out like fireworks on your tongue. Sooo delicious. Mains. I had the pan-roasted skuna bay salmon sofrito, with summer squash, smoked green olive, white anchovy mayonnaise. ($26). I love my salmon and this didn't disappoint me at all. My wife had the fried chicken with savoy cabbage slaw, black eyed pea vinaigrette, smoked jalapeno buttermilk ($22). I want to go back and order it myself. Amazing chicken. Service. Nice and attentive. Two of the original founding owners are still doing an epic job here. Ambiance. Cozy, comforting and intimate. If you want to learn something then sit at the chef's bar. Better make reservations. The place is small and the food is incredible.

The restaurant space is kind of cramped. It's tight. The menu has a unique flair for its take on simple American food like fried chicken and meatloaf. Basically it's just more expensive American food like fried chicken and meatloaf. We tried those two dishes, the pork chop, macaroni and cheese, and pea salad. I think it was unique place to try, but it's not a place I'd go to regularly.

Came all the way from Texas to have my birthday dinner here. Service was fantastic, waitress was an absolute joy. Food was great. We had the mac and cheese, which is a must, fried chicken and meatloaf. The meatloaf was weird but really good. It wasn't the densely packed meatloaf of the south, so, I was a little weirded out at first, but in the end I loved it. The key lime pie is the best I have ever had!! Go, eat, you won't be disappointed!

Feasted here a few days ago - good service, good wine, yummy, relatable food with complex flavors - yum!

Yes, yes and yes. Amazing food, prices are right, unique ambiance, excellent staff, cool owner. One of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco, no question. Love you Blue Plate!

Exceptional! I took my husband here for his birthday dinner. Upon walking in, we were greeted and made to feel at home from start to finish. The restaurant made me feel like I was in someone's European home. My husband ordered the squid as an appetizer which was amazing! For entrees we had the fried chicken and meatloaf. The meatloaf was melt in your mouth heavenly. For dessert we split the key lime pie which was the best I have had!! I highly recommend this romantic restaurant for foodies and SF enthusiasts alike.

We came for restaurant week for their $40 dinner special. The restaurant itself is very cozy and cute, and the food is quite good to match. We got: - pastrami cured beets - this was a very interesting dish. The flavors were unlike anything i've tried before, and if you like beets, you should try this - toasted farro and slow egg - the best thing we got all night. The slow cooked egg was perfectly runny and was absolutely delicious mixed in with the farro and on top of toast. We asked for extra bread to continue eating this amazing dish, and they gave us freshly baked foccacia that was really delicious - dungeons crab and ricotto ravioli - the worst thing we got. Somehow every aspect of this dish was overly salty, from the sauce to the pasta to the pasta filling. Do not recommend. - fried chicken - REALLY good fried chicken, boneless and dark meat I think. It came with some sort of creamed green side dish that I didn't care for but the huge portion of fried chicken was totally worth it - key lime pie - very tart and key limey - coconut cream pie - not too coconut nor creamy - surprisingly delicious Overall this was a great restaurant week experience and if you are in the neighborhood, I'd suggest checking it out.

We went here for my bf's birthday dinner and were quite pleased with the overall experience. For apps, we had: Grilled local squid: 4/5 stars - Yum! It tasted fresh and came w a sauce that paired well with the squid. The quantity was spot on too. Brandade gnocchi: 5/5 stars - Everyone's fav!! Probably one of the best gnocchis I've ever had. They were like miniature pillows! Chicken liver and black truffle mousse: 1/5 stars - I didn't try this... But that's because my bf's mom and her bf's reaction made me not want to haha. It's paired with a toasted sourdough granola. However, they didn't really give that much and so we were confused as to how you were supposed to eat it. They were not fond of the mousse and actually informed our server that we didn't like it that much and she took it away for us. Mac and goat cheese: 4/5 stars - Another yum! Creamy and you can really taste the goat cheese. It was pretty heavy though. As for entrees: Pan-seared arctic char: 4/5 stars - The sear on the fish was spot on. It was paired with lentils which my bf's mom was very fond of. Overall, it was a good dish! Fried chicken: 4/5 stars - Pretty good for fried chicken! It came w a smoked jalapeno ranch and mac salad. I actually really liked this! Meat loaf: 3/5 stars - Didn't try this but my bf's mom's bf ordered it and he thought it was whatever. It came with really yummy mashed potatoes and string beans. He couldn't stop raving about the mashed potatoes lol. They were very light-tasting! Pork chop: 3.5/5 stars - Bf ordered this and it was a faaaaat porkchop lol. He thought it was whatever though. Nothing memorable. It came with overcooked kale haha. Desserts, yay!!!!! Brownie sundae: 5/5 stars - it came w coffee ice cream (my fav), chocolate sauce and candied almonds. The chocolate sauce was unlike any other chocolate sauce! Not sure how to describe it but it tasted like dark chocolate w a hint of licorice. The brownie bits were yum too. Coconut cream pie: 5/5 stars - Another fav of ours! The crust is always my fav part when it comes to pie and they nailed it. It was flaky and buttery. As for the pie itself, they did not skimp on the coconut! Their cream also tasted very fresh and home made. I'll be dreaming about this coconut cream pie... Service was attentive and friendly! When we told her we weren't very fond of the chicken liver mousse, she asked if we wanted anything else but we were ok, and she also took it off our tab as well. How sweet! I sort of liked their small plates more than their entrees. I feel like the entrees were a little underwhelming. But overall, it was a nice experience! FYI - corkage fee is $20

A really cute dinner spot with delicious bread and upscale comfort food. That pretty much sums it up! Like others said, you might end up coming out smelling like smoke if you sit near the grill/kitchen open area. We had to wait 1.5 hours for this homey comfort food joint on a Saturday night and still, the 3 of us had to sit at the counter so it was kind of harder to talk. We ordered so much food just because we wanted to try everything! Sitting next to the kitchen is so tempting because everything looks soooo good. Pork belly appetizer (1 piece, and a few mussels, it tasted amazing!..definitely recommend getting this, it melts in your mouth) Beet Salad - I love beets!!!!! and this really surprised me, because of how well they hid the beet-y root taste. It was yellow and orange beets with a light vinaigrette dressing. I highly recommend this to get some vegetables in your meal, beets are good for you! ;) Cauliflower soup was surprising, i liked the truffle oil twist, which really made the flavor delicious. Coconut Cream Pie was just as it sounds, very coconutty and the crust was thin and layered. The Meat Loaf is a must, though I thought it was a little salty, but regardless, it was probably the best meat loaf I've ever tasted. The ribeye was pretty standard, but don't get the Scallops! They give you 3 medium sized grilled scallops and some veggies which is so not worth $24. I just thought it was overpriced for what it was, especially since 3 scallops can't get you full. Nonetheless, the grilled scallops were tasty and everything was well presented! I saw how much detail the chefs put into each entree and starter to make it perfect, and it just amazed me that everything wasn't made in humongous quantities and just scooped out when someone ordered it. Every time someone ordered, they really took their time to perfect the plate, and the presentation. I'd definitely come back here, because I heard they change their menus time to time, and only the meat loaf is a constant item on it!

I picked Blue Plate for a business dinner with an important guest. Everyone was happy - the salmon and the oyster mushroom lasagna were especially complimented. I had the meatloaf because I was curious how a nice place would turn it into a feature. It was tasty, with a blend of meats and spices, but the texture was not quite my style. Practically dessert. So buttery. Hard to stop eating! Calamari was exceptional, fresh and paired with some good herbs and a light dressing, and gnocchi got some rave reviews. I came here on Friday for restaurant week and I must say that after our three-course meal, I am definitely a fan! We were first served some warm foccacia bread, which tasted amazing! A little too delicious since we ended up getting seconds and felt a bit full before the actual courses came. My friend and I decided to get different items off the menu and share. I started with the toasted farro and slow egg while she got the cauliflower and vanilla bisque soup. Both had a ton of different flavors that went really well together. For the main course, I got the duck and pistachio ravioli while she got the artichoke risotto with oyster mushrooms. I preferred the ravioli and actually thought the sour cherry were a nice touch that added some sweetness to the duck flavor. The risotto also seemed quite good, but I ended up too full to enjoy too much of it. Finally, we got the key lime pie and butterscotch pudding. By this point, we were both stuffed, but I always have another stomach for sweets. The key lime was the right amount of sourness and I loved how pecan brittle came with the pudding to add a little saltiness to the sweet. Overall, it was a great experience and I would definitely consider coming back in the future! Might be a little pricey when it's not the $40 prefixe 3 course meal since the ravioli, which had 3 pieces, would've been $27. The service was top-notch, though, and I thoroughly enjoyed our meal.

Blue Plate is a hidden Gem! It was very welcoming, cozy, friendly, with great service. The food is absolutely terrific. We had a variety of appetizers which were so delicious. We were full after that, but here came our entrees. The Meatloaf was so soft and bursting with flavor, the Mashed Potatoes was super tasty, this was definatly my favorite till I had a piece of Pork Chops from my husband, it too was so soft and juicy then I tried a piece of fried chicken and that was super super crunchy and juicy too. OMG! Best ever! So I have to say that everything was my favorite. I wish we had more time to go back and try all the Appetizers, Entrees and Desserts. You rarely see Owners that are hands on and having conversations with their customers. Love, love, love this restaurant. My girlfriends and I chose this place for a celebratory girls nite. Place is intimate (aka small) but the decor and ambiance made it cozy. Service was superb as our waitress, Megan, was very knowledgeable about the menu. Since we were a "difficult" bunch (half of us had food sensitivities,) she was able to recommend alternatives and make modifications to our order. I ordered the grilled wagyu culotte and it was perfectly done medium well. Most of my friends ordered theirs medium rare, and it was truly medium rare. We splurged and ordered chocolate cake and the lemon sorbet for dessert. I couldn't eat the chocolate cake, but heard accolades from those who finished the entire plate of cake and ice cream. The lemon sorbet was so refreshing and had a fresh taste of lemon. Luckily, we all wore forgiving dresses to dinner because we definitely all had food babies by the end of dinner. Well done!

For me, this is pure excitement. Okay, I'm admitting, I'm a food nerd. I bought about 10 new Restaurant.com certificates for restaurants I've never been to. Blue Plate is the first certificate of the batch. Yay! I've lived in San Francisco most of my life, growing up in the Bernal Heights and Mission District. Blue Plate is close to my old stomping grounds and has been on my "To Eat" List for quite some time. Comfort foods are a favorite of mine and I'm looking to try all the best spots in the city. I had a very good friend in town and after talking about my new hobby, I decided that he should join me in the fun. We arrived without reservations and were able to be seated right away. We noticed immediately that this was a warm, comfortable restaurant, the lights were dimmed and it was a perfect place for a nice dinner and conversation. Our waitress was very nice, I tried to order a Pinot Gregio which they did not have. She referred the Gavi, which was a nice Italian White Wine, very light and crisp. I love it when people actually know their wines and can refer you to something you've never tried before and you would order again and again. We went straight to the main course: I ordered the Southern fried chicken thighs with buttermilk dressing with heirloom tomato, watermelon, watermelon rind salad with nicoise olives and basil. UNBELIEVABLY GOOD. The Fried Chicken was so moist, served hot and delicious. The Watermelon salad was cool, crisp and flavorful. They both went really well together, balancing out each other and worth it. He ordered the Blue plate meatloaf with mashed potatoes and blue lake green beans. A signature dish, but he picked it based on the whole concept of blue plate type comfort food dining. It was such a winner, normally you would think this would be heavy, but the meatloaf melted in your mouth and the mashed potatoes were whipped and light. This dish is really incredible and not your typical meatloaf dinner. Normally I would skip desert, but since it was all about the experience we decided to indulge. We ordered the Dark Chocolate Cake filled with Fleur de Sel Caramel center and accompanied by a scoop of chocolate chip ice cream. Again, the rich cake with the creamy caramel was perfect with the cool creaminess of the ice cream. It was like they were meant to be. It was a perfect meal, we both loved what we ordered and were pleasantly surprised that after such a filling meal, we were not over stuffed. Like I said, just perfect.

The Blue Plate is definitely comfort food, but with a bougie flair. Traditional blue plate meals are served on those metal plates that you'd find in a mess hall, segmented into three sections for your gruel and boiled chicken. It then became a diner special, meat and some sides. You would probably be served by someone named Dolores, and it would cost less that five dollars. But of course, in San Francisco, the blue plate special is something very special indeed. When I first walked into Blue Plate, my olfactory cortex was excited by the savory smells emanating from the kitchen. It's as if the chefs were sauteing spices just for the aromatics. Never had I been so happy that there was an open kitchen, and that I was seated near it. My friend and I thought long and hard about what to order; the menu was in its prime near the end of summer. I'll spare you the details of the menu; it's seasonal and not your average blue plate special. I remember being very impressed with the heirloom tomato soup, rabbit gnocchi, halibut, and ribeye. Oh, that's what we had! And some nice Oregonian Pinot Noir. I duct taped my mouth before trying to order the mac and cheese, because I was afraid I would need emergency services to help me leave. I'm getting sleepy and lazy just yelping about it. The Blue Plate is bustling with happy patrons, friendly servers, piqued taste buds, and locally sourced specials. It may be rustic, but we're definitely not in Kansas anymore.

Really great food, ambiance and wait staff. Ordered the grilled squid and fried chicken substituted with mashed potatoes. Couldn't be happier with everything and really enjoyed watching the kitchen perform service in the front portion of the kitchen. Service was very friendly and attentive, don't be surprised to see it busy on weekdays.

I am very happy with my life and there are very few things that I would like to change. One of them is, not surprisingly, that I would like my paycheck to grow. I specifically want it to grow so I can eat here more often. Everyday, I hop of the bus and look longingly inside at all the people whose taste buds are about to embark on a cruise of flavor. I love sitting at the bar and watching the kitchen work. The level of finesse and detail is great to see and I always find it an inspiring experience. So the food. Their Mac and Cheese is really good but so is everything else. I would say skip it for something more seasonal. Their appetizers have such unique taste combinations that we have frequently gone tapas style just so we can try them all. And good god, if there is pie on the dessert menu, get it. Get it.

Oh my. Rocken good food tonight. They do comfort food with a twist! All our food knocks our socks off. Even the mestloaf was good. But the pork chop really shines. The small plates offer clean, bright flavors that suprise even the most jaded taste-buds.

Loved these guys. This was supposed to be dinner date 2 for our anniversary weekend and it was one of the best meals I've had in the city. We arrived on Super Bowl sunday about 30 minutes prior to dinner and the head chef politely asked us to go to the corner bar and then come back when they were ready. He was extremely nice and he was right about the bar- it had a back patio, which was great for a quick drink. We were given a table next to the restaurants back patio and the lights were turned on. It's a wonderful cozy and intimate yet fun and quirky. Either way, it's great for date night without the big fuss. Going back to the food, this is what we had: nettle soup, brussel sprouts, fried chicken with the macaroni salad and the home made pasta with dungeness crab. I'm going to be blunt- the service is wonderful, we had the lemonade, which was sweet but not overwhelming. The food was carefully prepared and my husband loved, loved his freaking fried chicken. This is a guy who rarely likes fried chicken and he adored it. I think had he not had lunch prior to dinner, he would have ordered a second serving of it. I can't begin to mention the pasta with crab. It was delicious, soft, full of flavor of the garlic, the small bit of chilies, the crab was everywhere and I mean full of it. This by far has been my favorite meal and I thank the chef for this, especially since I've been sick this past month with bronchitis, this was my light at the end of the tunnel.

Focaccia bread is really amazing. Not a fan of the beet salad, even though beer is usually earthy tasting this tasted very charcoaly. Squid also tasted burnt but the texture was good. Main course- artichoke risotto. Cream and good consistency but I have definitely had better risotto. Overall the food was mediocre despite the obvious attempt at being unique. It was also pretty expensive for not being all that amazing.

    We came for restaurant week for their $40 dinner special. The restaurant itself is very cozy and cute, and the food is quite good to match.

    We got:
    - pastrami cured beets - this was a very interesting dish. The flavors were unlike anything i've tried before, and if you like beets, you should try this
    - toasted farro and slow egg - the best thing we got all night. The slow cooked egg was perfectly runny and was absolutely delicious mixed in with the farro and on top of toast. We asked for extra bread to continue eating this amazing dish, and they gave us freshly baked foccacia that was really delicious
    - dungeons crab and ricotto ravioli - the worst thing we got. Somehow every aspect of this dish was overly salty, from the sauce to the pasta to the pasta filling. Do not recommend.
    - fried chicken - REALLY good fried chicken, boneless and dark meat I think. It came with some sort of creamed green side dish that I didn't care for but the huge portion of fried chicken was totally worth it
    - key lime pie - very tart and key limey
    - coconut cream pie - not too coconut nor creamy - surprisingly delicious

    Overall this was a great restaurant week experience and if you are in the neighborhood, I'd suggest checking it out.

It's paired with a toasted sourdough granola. However, they didn't really give that much and so we were confused as to how you were supposed to eat it. They were not fond of the mousse and actually informed our server that we didn't like it that much and she took it away for us.

    Mac and goat cheese: 4/5 stars - Another yum! Creamy and you can really taste the goat cheese. It was pretty heavy though.

    As for entrees:
    Pan-seared arctic char: 4/5 stars - The sear on the fish was spot on. It was paired with lentils which my bf's mom was very fond of. Overall, it was a good dish!

    Fried chicken: 4/5 stars - Pretty good for fried chicken! It came w a smoked jalapeno ranch and mac salad. I actually really liked this!

    Meat loaf: 3/5 stars - Didn't try this but my bf's mom's bf ordered it and he thought it was whatever. It came with really yummy mashed potatoes and string beans. He couldn't stop raving about the mashed potatoes lol. They were very light-tasting!

    Pork chop: 3.5/5 stars - Bf ordered this and it was a faaaaat porkchop lol. He thought it was whatever though. Nothing memorable. It came with overcooked kale haha.

    Desserts, yay!!!!!
    Brownie sundae: 5/5 stars - it came w coffee ice cream (my fav), chocolate sauce and candied almonds. The chocolate sauce was unlike any other chocolate sauce! Not sure how to describe it but it tasted like dark chocolate w a hint of licorice. The brownie bits were yum too.

    Coconut cream pie: 5/5 stars - Another fav of ours! The crust is always my fav part when it comes to pie and they nailed it. It was flaky and buttery. As for the pie itself, they did not skimp on the coconut! Their cream also tasted very fresh and home made. I'll be dreaming about this coconut cream pie...

    Service was attentive and friendly! When we told her we weren't very fond of the chicken liver mousse, she asked if we wanted anything else but we were ok, and she also took it off our tab as well. How sweet! I sort of liked their small plates more than their entrees. I feel like the entrees were a little underwhelming. But overall, it was a nice experience!

    A really cute dinner spot with delicious bread and upscale comfort food.

    That pretty much sums it up! Like others said, you might end up coming out smelling like smoke if you sit near the grill/kitchen open area. We had to wait 1.5 hours for this homey comfort food joint on a Saturday night and still, the 3 of us had to sit at the counter so it was kind of harder to talk.

    We ordered so much food just because we wanted to try everything! Sitting next to the kitchen is so tempting because everything looks soooo good.

    Pork belly appetizer (1 piece, and a few mussels, it tasted amazing!..definitely recommend getting this, it melts in your mouth)

    Beet Salad - I love beets!!!!! and this really surprised me, because of how well they hid the beet-y root taste. It was yellow and orange beets with a light vinaigrette dressing. I highly recommend this to get some vegetables in your meal, beets are good for you! ;)

    Cauliflower soup was surprising, i liked the truffle oil twist, which really made the flavor delicious.

    Coconut Cream Pie was just as it sounds, very coconutty and the crust was thin and layered.

    The Meat Loaf is a must, though I thought it was a little salty, but regardless, it was probably the best meat loaf I've ever tasted.

    The ribeye was pretty standard, but don't get the Scallops! They give you 3 medium sized grilled scallops and some veggies which is so not worth $24. I just thought it was overpriced for what it was, especially since 3 scallops can't get you full. Nonetheless, the grilled scallops were tasty and everything was well presented! I saw how much detail the chefs put into each entree and starter to make it perfect, and it just amazed me that everything wasn't made in humongous quantities and just scooped out when someone ordered it. Every time someone ordered, they really took their time to perfect the plate, and the presentation. I'd definitely come back here, because I heard they change their menus time to time, and only the meat loaf is a constant item on it!

    I came here on Friday for restaurant week and I must say that after our three-course meal, I am definitely a fan!

    We were first served some warm foccacia bread, which tasted amazing! A little too delicious since we ended up getting seconds and felt a bit full before the actual courses came. My friend and I decided to get different items off the menu and share. I started with the toasted farro and slow egg while she got the cauliflower and vanilla bisque soup. Both had a ton of different flavors that went really well together. For the main course, I got the duck and pistachio ravioli while she got the artichoke risotto with oyster mushrooms. I preferred the ravioli and actually thought the sour cherry were a nice touch that added some sweetness to the duck flavor. The risotto also seemed quite good, but I ended up too full to enjoy too much of it. Finally, we got the key lime pie and butterscotch pudding. By this point, we were both stuffed, but I always have another stomach for sweets. The key lime was the right amount of sourness and I loved how pecan brittle came with the pudding to add a little saltiness to the sweet.

    Overall, it was a great experience and I would definitely consider coming back in the future! Might be a little pricey when it's not the $40 prefixe 3 course meal since the ravioli, which had 3 pieces, would've been $27. The service was top-notch, though, and I thoroughly enjoyed our meal.

    My girlfriends and I chose this place for a celebratory girls nite.

    Place is intimate (aka small) but the decor and ambiance made it cozy.

    Service was superb as our waitress, Megan, was very knowledgeable about the menu. Since we were a "difficult" bunch (half of us had food sensitivities,) she was able to recommend alternatives and make modifications to our order.

    I ordered the grilled wagyu culotte and it was perfectly done medium well. Most of my friends ordered theirs medium rare, and it was truly medium rare.

    We splurged and ordered chocolate cake and the lemon sorbet for dessert. I couldn't eat the chocolate cake, but heard accolades from those who finished the entire plate of cake and ice cream. The lemon sorbet was so refreshing and had a fresh taste of lemon.

    Luckily, we all wore forgiving dresses to dinner because we definitely all had food babies by the end of dinner. Well done!

    For me, this is pure excitement. Okay, I'm admitting, I'm a food nerd. I bought about 10 new Restaurant.com certificates for restaurants I've never been to. Blue Plate is the first certificate of the batch. Yay!

    I've lived in San Francisco most of my life, growing up in the Bernal Heights and Mission District. Blue Plate is close to my old stomping grounds and has been on my "To Eat" List for quite some time.  Comfort foods are a favorite of mine and I'm looking to try all the best spots in the city.  I had a very good friend in town and after talking about my new hobby, I decided that he should join me in the fun.

    We arrived without reservations and were able to be seated right away.  We noticed immediately that this was a warm, comfortable restaurant, the lights were dimmed and it was a perfect place for a nice dinner and conversation.  Our waitress was very nice, I tried to order a Pinot Gregio which they did not have. She referred the Gavi, which was a nice Italian White Wine, very light and crisp.  I love it when people actually know their wines and can refer you to something you've never tried before and you would order again and again.

    We went straight to the main course:

    I ordered the Southern fried chicken thighs with buttermilk dressing with heirloom tomato, watermelon, watermelon rind salad with nicoise olives and basil.  UNBELIEVABLY GOOD. The Fried Chicken was so moist, served hot and delicious. The Watermelon salad was cool, crisp and flavorful. They both went really well together, balancing out each other and worth it.

    He ordered the Blue plate meatloaf with mashed potatoes and blue lake green beans. A signature dish,  but he picked it based on the whole concept of blue plate type comfort food dining. It was such a winner, normally you would think this would be heavy, but the meatloaf melted in your mouth and the mashed potatoes were whipped and light. This dish is really incredible and not your typical meatloaf dinner.

    Normally I would skip desert, but since it was all about the experience we decided to indulge. We ordered the Dark Chocolate Cake filled with Fleur de Sel Caramel center and accompanied by a scoop of chocolate chip ice cream.  Again, the rich cake with the creamy caramel was perfect with the cool creaminess of the ice cream. It was like they were meant to be.

    It was a perfect meal, we both loved what we ordered and were pleasantly surprised that after such a filling meal, we were not over stuffed. Like I said, just perfect.

    11/11/2010

    11 photos

    2 check-ins

    The Blue Plate is definitely comfort food, but with a bougie flair.

    Traditional blue plate meals are served on those metal plates that you'd find in a mess hall, segmented into three sections for your gruel and boiled chicken. It then became a diner special, meat and some sides. You would probably be served by someone named Dolores, and it would cost less that five dollars.

    But of course, in San Francisco, the blue plate special is something very special indeed.

    When I first walked into Blue Plate, my olfactory cortex was excited by the savory smells emanating from the kitchen. It's as if the chefs were sauteing spices just for the aromatics. Never had I been so happy that there was an open kitchen, and that I was seated near it.

    My friend and I thought long and hard about what to order; the menu was in its prime near the end of summer.  I'll spare you the details of the menu; it's seasonal and not your average blue plate special. I remember being very impressed with the heirloom tomato soup, rabbit gnocchi, halibut, and ribeye. Oh, that's what we had! And some nice Oregonian Pinot Noir. I duct taped my mouth before trying to order the mac and cheese, because I was afraid I would need emergency services to help me leave. I'm getting sleepy and lazy just yelping about it.

    The Blue Plate is bustling with happy patrons, friendly servers, piqued taste buds, and locally sourced specials.

    It may be rustic, but we're definitely not in Kansas anymore.

    Loved these guys. This was supposed to be dinner date 2 for our anniversary weekend and it was one of the best meals I've had in the city. We arrived on Super Bowl sunday about 30 minutes prior to dinner and the head chef politely asked us to go to the corner bar and then come back when they were ready. He was extremely nice and he was right about the bar- it had a back patio, which was great for a quick drink.

    We were given a table next to the restaurants back patio and the lights were turned on. It's a wonderful cozy and intimate yet fun and quirky. Either way, it's great for date night without the big fuss.

    Going back to the food, this is what we had: nettle soup, brussel sprouts, fried chicken with the macaroni salad and the home made pasta with dungeness crab. I'm going to be blunt- the service is wonderful, we had the lemonade, which was sweet but not overwhelming. The food was carefully prepared and my husband loved, loved his freaking fried chicken. This is a guy who rarely likes fried chicken and he adored it. I think had he not had lunch prior to dinner, he would have ordered a second serving of it.

    I can't begin to mention the pasta with crab. It was delicious, soft, full of flavor of the garlic, the small bit of chilies, the crab was everywhere and I mean full of it. This by far has been my favorite meal and I thank the chef for this, especially since I've been sick this past month with bronchitis, this was my light at the end of the tunnel.
